text.p: These are the leading stories in the Albanian press on Wednesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
KOHA JONE

- Seven Albanian opposition parties will not take part in a general election next month after the dominant Democratic Party passed its own election law instead of considering a draft drawn up by the nine-party government.
- The paper questions whether 400-strong force of Albanians training near the capital is destined toi reinforce troops guarding Albanian President Sali Berisha.
- Italy's Defence undersecretary Massimo Brutti promised armoured cars, bullet-proof vests, uniforms and radios for police in the bandit-ridden town of Vlore.
- Albanian Prime Minister Bashkim Fino said the U.S. administration backed his demand for the multinational protection force to protect the voting in a general election.
- U.S. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright could visit Tirana before parliamentary elections scheduled in June.
- The United States said it would reinstate its $12 million economic and technical aid to Albania.
- The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank will not offer compensation to Albanians who lost their life saving in pyramid investment schemes, Finance Minister Arben Malaj said.
GAZETA SHQIPTARE
- The Democratic Party's electoral law endangers early elections as it ignores the draft law backed by nine political parties in the national reconciliation government.
- Vlore chief police Milto Kordha resigned after violence spread in the port town where dozens of people have been killed over the past days.
- Parliament passed a decree of President Sali Berisha to allow a referendum on restoring the monarchy to take place on June 29, the same day as planned parliamentary elections.
- Petro Koci, a local Socialist Party leader was held for two hours in the Fieri district by unknown gunmen who allegedly asked him to stop criticising Democrat MPs, the paper says.
- The Greek consulate in Gjirokaster was closed due to lack of security in this bandit-ridden town.
- Berat town where about 80 people have killed since beginning of March is in the hands of bandits.
ALBANIA
- Berisha is expected to announce a date for a general election today.
- Parliament will be dissolved today to open the way to elections.
- Italy thinks a neutral police force should be organised in Albania, visiting Italian deputy defence minister Massimo Bruti said.
RILINDJA DEMOKRATIKE
- The Socialists return to their policy of boycott, the paper says, after the party threatened not to participate in elections unless the government draft electoral law is passed by parliament.
